crnrstn_element.crnrstn_description:
When cookies need to be incorporated into a users experience, the cookie_manager :: class of the CRNRSTN Suite :: can handle most (if not all) of the common tasks associated with that client facing functionality. If security is a concern, there are methods for storing and retrieving cookie data that will leverage the mcrypt library compiled with your installation of PHP. Aside from augmented functionalities such as data encryption and batch processing, this class sits very close to the existing support that is provided by PHP for handling cookies.
ProTip: If the CRNRSTN Suite :: has been initialized via initCookieEncryption() to apply an encryption layer to the cookie management process, there are special methods for encryption that must be used. See examples and documentation on the following methods for that functionality: addEncryptedCookie(), getEncryptedCookie() and deleteEncryptedCookie().
Neither addCookie() nor the cookie_manager constructor...for example...have access to the cipher-based encryption layer.

crnrstn_techspecscontent.crnrstn_techspec: Currently tested on an ubuntu 4.2 server running PHP Version 5.2.6 and Apache 2.2.11. The method addRawCookie() is not supported by PHP 5.
Certain methods may require that PHP be compiled with mcrypt if CRNRSTN has been configured to run on encryption.
It is recommended that you upgrade to the latest version of PHP to take advantage of the latests gains in security and processing efficiency.
Supports cookies with multiple values...up to 4 dimensions (e.g. cookie-name[0][1][a][b]="value").
